attachments.title: Amy Schumer, Avowed Feminist, Continues to Be Clueless About Feminism
attachments.text: It makes me very sad to report that "I Love You, Amy Schumer, But You're Wrong" has become an evergreen headline. In August, I rolled it out when Schumer failed to disavow the misogynist garbage spewed by Inside Amy Schumer writer Kurt Metzger. This time, it applies to a horrendous "tribute" video she made starring herself and other mostly white women lip-synching to Beyoncé's "Formation." It's a bad video that erases the provenance, audience, and...
attachments.fallback: Portland Mercury: Amy Schumer, Avowed Feminist, Continues to Be Clueless About Feminism

text: amy schumer is a fuckboy
I am a REALLY BIG fan of Amy Schumer. But that is really dumb.
Hey all, remember this dialog channel and not for hatin’ on anybody! Keep stuff open and informative!

Not pictured: Amy Schumer getting permission from Beyonce and Jay-Z. <http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/amy-schumer-defends-formation-video-against-racism-charges-w447259> 
I dunno. I'm on both sides of this one. I LOVE AMY SCHUMER. I have seen every episode of her show, every joke on stand up, I'm reading her book currently. I identify with her a lot. Like a lot of us, Amy could use some help identifying her blind spots but her intentions were clearly good. We talked earlier about how intentions are NOT an excuse and I still agree with that. But I also think that particular article (and actually many of them) are harsh. Amy Schumer idolizes Beyonce in the same way many of us do. It feels like an amateur video that I might make with my friends in homage to Beyonce and her amazingness.

attachments.title: Amy Schumer Defends 'Formation' Video Against Racism Charges
attachments.text: Amy Schumer defended her lighthearted spin on Beyoncé's "Formation" video against accusations of racism in a post detailing her intentions.
attachments.fallback: Rolling Stone: Amy Schumer Defends 'Formation' Video Against Racism Charges

text: The correct thing would be to say "I'm sorry, and I'll learn from this and do better", but it seems Amy's not at that point yet

i recognize the challenge of celebrity and issues, but have always felt there’s some dimension to comedy that takes bigger risks and is going to play out of the zone. and maybe that actually helps the conversation. i always think about the comedian who first made a 9/11 joke on a big stage.
I’m sorry, I shouldn’t have said that. I really dislike Amy Schumer, but should have a more constructive expression of that.
